bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Otto L. Bettmann, January 12, 1948

div1.p: Hench returns the yellow fever photographs to Bettmann, along with photos of William and Charles Mayo for Bettmann's collection of well-known American doctors.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Otto L. Bettmann, January 12, 1948
div1.opener:
Y, F,
January 12, 1948
Dr. Otto L. Bettmann, Director,
The Bettmann Archive
211A East Fifty-Seventh Street
New York 22, New York
My dear Doctor Bettmann:
div1.p:
I regret sincerely my delay in returning to you the yellow fever
pictures. I laid them aside until such time as I could also send you the
photographs of Dr. Will and Charlie Mayo. We had a little trouble locating
the old negatives and had to print several of them. I am sending you with
the yellow fever paintings a collection of pictures of Dr. Will and Charlie,
11 items in all. I could not locate an informal picture of either of them
in front of the Clinic. I have many informal pictures but none in front of
the Clinic. Three of the pictures are of paintings of Doctor Will and
Charlie and most of us like them very much. The one double picture of
Doctor Will and Charlie shows representations of their autographs, not
actual autographs, but they are very close to the original as they were
done by Doctor Will's secretary who had long learned to imitate the signa-
ture. The photographic copies of Doctor Will and Charlie in uniform, however,
actually show their autographs. The picture of Doctor Will and Charlie with
President Roosevelt was taken at a public ceremony, August 8, 1938, when
President Roosevelt came to honor Doctor Will and Charlie. It was taken
by a newspaper photographer. Keep those which you wish to have and return
the rest. I enclose also photographic prints of Dr. William W. Mayo, the
father of Doctor Will and Charlie and a copy of a rather rare photograph
of the three Mayos (father and two sons) taken early in their career here.

In order to be able to send you these, I had to get permission
of certain authorities here as the Clinic is very careful about improper
publicity. We understand that you wish to use these in your collection of
well-known American doctors. We understand that they will be reproduced
from time to time but we are relying on your discretion as to how they are used
so that they will be only used in a proper and dignified manner by authorized
persons.

It is not necessary, indeed I would suggest that you not pass on to
others that you got these from me.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
Pictures sent insured.
